trans-unit.source: Light probes
trans-unit.target: Light probes

trans-unit.source: Beginner Designer Artist
trans-unit.target: Beginner Designer Artist

trans-unit.source: Light probes capture the lighting at the position you place them. They simulate indirect light, the effect of light bouncing off surfaces and illuminating other surfaces. They can make a dramatic difference to the mood and appearance of your scene.
trans-unit.target: Light probes capture the lighting at the position you place them. They simulate indirect light, the effect of light bouncing off surfaces and illuminating other surfaces. They can make a dramatic difference to the mood and appearance of your scene.

trans-unit.source: The screenshot below shows a point light surrounded by light probes in the Scene Editor. The probes form 3D areas (shown in the Scene Editor by the yellow wireframe connecting the probes).
trans-unit.target: The screenshot below shows a point light surrounded by light probes in the Scene Editor. The probes form 3D areas (shown in the Scene Editor by the yellow wireframe connecting the probes).

trans-unit.source: Cornell box
trans-unit.target: Cornell box

trans-unit.source: Stride colors pixels within a light probe area to simulate the effect of light bouncing from nearby surfaces. To find a color for a given pixel, Stride interpolates from the lighting captured by the four surrounding light probes.
trans-unit.target: Stride colors pixels within a light probe area to simulate the effect of light bouncing from nearby surfaces. To find a color for a given pixel, Stride interpolates from the lighting captured by the four surrounding light probes.

trans-unit.source: For example, in the screenshot below, notice how the red of the wall is reflected on the other objects. In the Scene Editor, this is also visible on the surface of the light probes themselves.
trans-unit.target: For example, in the screenshot below, notice how the red of the wall is reflected on the other objects. In the Scene Editor, this is also visible on the surface of the light probes themselves.

trans-unit.source: Light probes — more reflection
trans-unit.target: Light probes — more reflection

trans-unit.source: Light probes affect all objects in the area they cover, including static and dynamic objects. You don't need to enable any extra options on the entities that light probes affect.
trans-unit.target: Light probes affect all objects in the area they cover, including static and dynamic objects. You don't need to enable any extra options on the entities that light probes affect.

trans-unit.source: 1. Enable light probes in the graphics compositor
trans-unit.target: 1. Enable light probes in the graphics compositor

trans-unit.source: Stride enables light probes by default in new projects. To make sure light probes are enabled:
trans-unit.target: Stride enables light probes by default in new projects. To make sure light probes are enabled:

trans-unit.source: In the Asset View (in the bottom pane by default), double-click the Graphics Compositor asset.
trans-unit.target: In the Asset View (in the bottom pane by default), double-click the Graphics Compositor asset.

trans-unit.source: Graphics Compositor asset
trans-unit.target: Graphics Compositor asset

trans-unit.source: The graphics compositor editor opens.
trans-unit.target: The graphics compositor editor opens.

trans-unit.source: Graphics Compositor editor
trans-unit.target: Graphics Compositor editor

trans-unit.source: Select the forward renderer node.
trans-unit.target: Select the forward renderer node.

trans-unit.source: In the Property Grid (on the right by default), make sure the Light probes checkbox is selected.
trans-unit.target: In the Property Grid (on the right by default), make sure the Light probes checkbox is selected.

trans-unit.source: Enable light probes
trans-unit.target: Enable light probes

trans-unit.source: For more information about the graphics compositor, see the Graphics compositor page.
trans-unit.target: For more information about the graphics compositor, see the Graphics compositor page.

trans-unit.source: 2. Create a light probe
trans-unit.target: 2. Create a light probe

trans-unit.source: Right-click the scene or Entity Tree and select Light > Light probe.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the scene or Entity Tree and select Light > Light probe.

trans-unit.source: Add light probe
trans-unit.target: Add light probe

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, create an empty entity and add a Light probe component in the Property Grid.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, create an empty entity and add a Light probe component in the Property Grid.

trans-unit.source: Add light probe component
trans-unit.target: Add light probe component

trans-unit.source: Light probes appear as spheres in the Scene Editor. Before you capture a light bounce for the first time, they have a completely black surface.
trans-unit.target: Light probes appear as spheres in the Scene Editor. Before you capture a light bounce for the first time, they have a completely black surface.

trans-unit.source: Light
trans-unit.target: Light

trans-unit.source: 3. Place light probes
trans-unit.target: 3. Place light probes

trans-unit.source: Light probes must be placed in a way that creates a 3D volume. This means:
trans-unit.target: Light probes must be placed in a way that creates a 3D volume. This means:

trans-unit.source: You need at least four light probes in the scene — enough to create the four points of a tetrahedron, as below:
trans-unit.target: You need at least four light probes in the scene — enough to create the four points of a tetrahedron, as below:

trans-unit.source: Tetrahedron
trans-unit.target: Tetrahedron

trans-unit.source: At least one light probe must be on a different plane from the rest. For example, the probes in the screenshot below won't work, as they are on a flat plane and create no volume:
trans-unit.target: At least one light probe must be on a different plane from the rest. For example, the probes in the screenshot below won't work, as they are on a flat plane and create no volume:

trans-unit.source: Flat probes
trans-unit.target: Flat probes

trans-unit.source: A typical method is to place light probes in a grid across your scene covering a general area, as in the screenshots below:
trans-unit.target: A typical method is to place light probes in a grid across your scene covering a general area, as in the screenshots below:

trans-unit.source: Grid layout
trans-unit.target: Grid layout

trans-unit.source: Light probes in the editor
trans-unit.target: Light probes in the editor

trans-unit.source: !Tip You can quickly duplicate light probes just like other entities. To do this, select a light probe, hold Ctrl, and move it with the mouse.
trans-unit.target: !Tip You can quickly duplicate light probes just like other entities. To do this, select a light probe, hold Ctrl, and move it with the mouse.

trans-unit.source: 4. Capture lighting
trans-unit.target: 4. Capture lighting

trans-unit.source: In the Scene Editor toolbar, click the lighting options button to open the lighting options menu.
trans-unit.target: In the Scene Editor toolbar, click the lighting options button to open the lighting options menu.

trans-unit.source: Lighting options
trans-unit.target: Lighting options

trans-unit.source: Next to Bounces, set the number of light bounces you want to capture.
trans-unit.target: Next to Bounces, set the number of light bounces you want to capture.

trans-unit.source: Multiple bounces simulate the effect of light bouncing between surfaces multiple times. This generally has the effect of brightening the lighting. Three or four bounces should be enough; beyond this, changes are almost unnoticeable. The number of bounces has no impact on runtime performance.
trans-unit.target: Multiple bounces simulate the effect of light bouncing between surfaces multiple times. This generally has the effect of brightening the lighting. Three or four bounces should be enough; beyond this, changes are almost unnoticeable. The number of bounces has no impact on runtime performance.

trans-unit.source: To capture the lighting, click Compute.
trans-unit.target: To capture the lighting, click Compute.

trans-unit.source: You can see the lighting on the surface of the light probes in the Scene Editor.
trans-unit.target: You can see the lighting on the surface of the light probes in the Scene Editor.

trans-unit.source: Light probe surface
trans-unit.target: Light probe surface

trans-unit.source: Reset light probes
trans-unit.target: Reset light probes

trans-unit.source: To reset the light probes, in the lighting options menu, click Reset. This is useful after you change the lights in your scene and need to capture the lighting from scratch.
trans-unit.target: To reset the light probes, in the lighting options menu, click Reset. This is useful after you change the lights in your scene and need to capture the lighting from scratch.

trans-unit.source: Reset light probes
trans-unit.target: Reset light probes

trans-unit.source: Show and hide light probes in the Scene Editor
trans-unit.target: Show and hide light probes in the Scene Editor

trans-unit.source: Under the gizmo options in the Scene Editor toolbar, use the Light probes checkbox.
trans-unit.target: Under the gizmo options in the Scene Editor toolbar, use the Light probes checkbox.

trans-unit.source: Hide light probes
trans-unit.target: Hide light probes

trans-unit.source: Show and hide light probe volumes in the Scene Editor
trans-unit.target: Show and hide light probe volumes in the Scene Editor

trans-unit.source: Under the gizmo options in the Scene Editor toolbar, use the Light probe volumes checkbox.
trans-unit.target: Under the gizmo options in the Scene Editor toolbar, use the Light probe volumes checkbox.

trans-unit.source: Hide light probe volumes
trans-unit.target: Hide light probe volumes

trans-unit.source: Light probe volumes on and off
trans-unit.target: Light probe volumes on and off
